bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Paul L. Tate, May 20, 1952

div1.p: Truby discusses his health problems. He comments on Standlee's history of Walter Reed Hospital. Truby suggests that it should be reviewed by some of the senior officers at the hospital.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Paul L. Tate, May 20, 1952
div1.opener:
Letterman Army Hospital
San Francisco, California
May 20, 1952
Mr. Paul L. Tate
1530 Tyler Street
Berkeley, California
Dear Tate:
div1.p:
Just received your card and will answer right away. I am continuing
to make very nice progress but it is terribly slow. I have been
here now just over three months and I think the progress from here
on should be more rapid. I still don't dare trust myself to use a
cane because I am too weak to catch myself if I should start to fall,
but that is the nature of this affliction of the spinal cord. The
doctor finally decided that I had a slight hemorrhage in the anterior
columns of the cord and feels that by this time the lesion should be
pretty well resolved and that progress from here on should be more
rapid.

While I have been here I have been reading Mrs. Standlee's manuscript
regarding the history of the Walter Reed Hospital. The manuscript
was so big and bulky that I could not lift it and I made no effort
to read it myself, so Mrs. Truby read it to me while I was in bed.
It has just been recently returned to her with the brief comments
I could make on such an elaborate affair. I enjoyed it thoroughly
although it could not be considered a factual story because practi-
cally all of the information she has is from others, and therefore
hearsay. Besides some of the people she quotes were not competent,
in my opinion, to express the opinions they did. It was all hearsay.
So, I think the whole story ought to be reviewed by some of the senior
officers there at the Walter Reed. It could be a very creditable
history if they can show by references that much of the data is
factual.

Her chapter on yellow fever, as it was first written, brought out
what I consider was discredited material about Carroll and Agramonte,
especially Dr. Hammeter's wholly unreliable material about Carroll.
The whole Corps was sore at Carroll at that time. I wrote her that
and suggested that she leave out that chapter entirely and make a
simple statement that that story is being written by Dr. Hench and
that he has more factual information on the subject than anyone
living. So, why try to do something that could not be done without
great expense and study? Her revised copy which came with the manuscript
was much improved but I still felt that I should stick to my first
remarks and ask her to leave it out.

In one of Mrs. Standlee's letters she mentioned you and appreciated
your interest in her book and was pleased with your comments.

I will probably be here a month or maybe more but as soon as I can
walk with safety by myself I shall try to get back home. I have been
busy with considerable correspondence to take care of and have not
been able to write each of my friends except occasionally.

closer.signed:
Albert E. Truby,
Brigadier General, Retired
U. S. Army
